name: 4-methoxy-N-[4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)phenyl]benzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3348

name: 4-methoxy-N-[4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)phenyl]benzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3348
Reason: The compound in question, 4-methoxy-N-[4-(2-phenyl-2H-benzotriazol-5-yl)phenyl]benzamide, is a large aromatic compound with several functional groups and structural features that influence its melting point: 1) Multiple benzene rings: each benzene ring contributes to an increase in the melting point due to pi-stacking and increased molecular weight. Actual benzene ring has a melting point of around 5.5. Predicting a +20 per additional benzene ring for a total of three rings results in +60. 2) Benzotriazole group: the presence of nitrogen atoms within the ring can lead to hydrogen bonding and greater molecular rigidity, which typically increases melting point. Estimating an increase of +20 due to the benzotriazole moiety. 3) Methoxy (–OCH3) group: an electron-donating group which might marginally lower the melting point due to a lesser degree of intermolecular hydrogen bonding compared to hydroxyl groups; estimating a −5 decrement. 4) Amide (–CONH–) group: contributes to the melting point through hydrogen bonding and resonance, leading to increased planarity and rigidity; estimating an increase of +30. As the base structure for comparison, we'll use benzene (5.5 °C). Summing these effects, we get a predicted melting point: Benzene base melting point +60 (3 benzene rings) +20 (benzotriazole) −5 (methoxy) +30 (amide) = 110.5 °C.
